results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film contains some of the Hayes family favourites – their assorted pets including the star of many of the films, Ticka the cockatoo, their farm animals and views of the areas surrounding their home in Heathmont. There is also a brief visit to the beach.

A feature of the film is some early views of Ringwood shops and traffic including good examples of cars of the day and the very new looking ‘Holden Bill Paterson Motors’. Bill Paterson was a successful racing car driver of his era. We also see advertising signs of the day such as ‘Whelan the Wrecker’ and ‘Dickies’ and a vintage ‘red rattler’ train crossing the Yarra so likely to be the Port Melbourne/St Kilda line now a lightrail.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

results.title: Rabbit Control [Part 1: Poisoning with 1080]
results.creator_credit: Conservation Forests and Lands, John Atkins and Ian Blythman
results.brief_description: This program narrated by Maurie Fields shows the problem of pest control in rural Victoria, and the adverse effects on farming if rabbit populations are not controlled. Part 1 explains the proper steps and procedure in using the poison 1080, the various safety precautions, equipment and supplies and tidy up details.

results.title: Using a computer catalogue
results.creator_credit: TV Ed Productions, Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group, Keith Rees, Jenny Craig and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Because of changing library information systems, computerised catalogues are increasingly being used to record, store and retrieve holdings in libraries. Ann Hannan demostrates how to use the OPAC (On Line Public Access Catalogue) System, which is a touch system used in public libraries.

results.title: This woman is not a car
results.creator_credit: Arid Zone Productions, Jenny Jacobs, Vyner Gillespie and Margaret Dodd
results.brief_description: A mother, isolated in an outer Adelaide suburb, drives a station wagon full of children to a distant beach. Imagination and reality fuse. Her sense of herself is assaulted by car fetishists in a rural service station. Memory, fear and fantasy are interwoven as this experimental film takes woman’s assigned role in the ‘Australian Dream’ to its absurd conclusion. Music: Brian Eno, The Fabulous Nudes, The Pelaco Bros. Actors include Pauline Sedgwick, Daniel Sedgwick, Lisa Sedgwick, Gareth Sedgwick and Katrina Sedgwick.

results.title: Wharfies: A History of the Waterside Worker's Federation
results.brief_description: Wharfies traces the history of the Australian Waterside Workers Federation from its foundation in 1902, under Billy Hughes, to the present day. Made in the tradition of the Waterside Workers Film Unit of the 1950s, “Wharfies” covers important historical events including industrial milestones, political crises and the stories of the men themselves. This film is pieced together through dramatised sequences, interviews with veteran wharfies and rare archival footage. Cartoons, news clippings and old photographs all help to tell the story.

results.title: Solid women = Moodeitj yorgas
results.creator_credit: Western Australian Women's Advisory Council to the Premier, Deborah Howlett and Tracey Moffatt
results.brief_description: This documentary about Aboriginal women today includes interviews with successful, strong Aboriginal women, including Sally Morgan, Lois Olney, Helen Corbett and Helen Dorondorf. Stills of Aboriginal people and the land, stories in two Aboriginal languages about their fate after the white man, and Aboriginal music and dance are presented between the interviews. The women raise issues about how the Aboriginal people can best help themselves, and recount their own life experiences and achievements. Highly successful, these women act as a foil to the bulk of information received through the media about Aboriginal people. They are positive role models for Aboriginal women and girls.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

In this film Kenneth and some fellow travellers visit the Grampians showing the varied scenery across the mountainous ranges and the valley, groups of people relaxing and enjoying natural surrounds as well as hiking and gathering for a picnic.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:07:00 title card ‘Our Grampians’ starts us off travelling along a country road where we see the sign to Halls Gap and other local towns, followed by a sign for “Hotel Bellfield” and a spot of golf.

00:00:02:00 ‘Splitter Falls’ sign appears ahead of more views of the mountainous range, roads and the valley below.
00:04:12:00 a very long waterfall.

00:04:57:00 a group of tourist overlooling the hills from a high vantage point.

00:05:13:00 a photographer setting up a spectacular looking shot of people sitting on rocks.

00:06:37:00 toasting bread on an open fire and the sign ‘New scenic track to McKenzie Falls’.

00:09:27:00 women holding a bunch of wildflowers one of whom sports a classic 40’s headscarf style.

00:10:21:00 we see a tree being prepared for felling by two mean using a double ended saw followed by a logging truck.

00:11:14:00 sign to ‘Wonderland’ followed by a large group of people trekking up a rocky incline, taking rests on the rocks, climbing narrow ravines and finally looking out from the top.

00:15:07:00 the travellers stand around a fire with a billy-can, cooking lambchops and bread.

00:17:12:00 a farmer and his tractor from a close view and pink tinged clouds.

results.title: Landholder Group Participation: a Model for Action
results.creator_credit: Warrenbayne Boho Land Protection Group and Peter Mountjoy
results.brief_description: Shows the process of landholders realising that the problems of salinity and erosion need to be tackled in groups rather than as individuals. Illustrates the establishment of the Warrenbayne Boho Land Protection Group. Shows the group working with Agriculture Extension Officers and Soil Conservation personnel, owning their involvement and taking responsibility for their actions. Useful as a model for people planning to establish community action groups.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Warrenbayne Boho Land Protection Group and Peter Mountjoy

results.title: Kanga Cricket
results.brief_description: An Australian Cricket Board primary development programme for kids, sponsored by the Australian Diary Corporation and supported by the Commonwealth Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism. Demonstrates the concept of Kanga cricket, a simplified adaptation of traditional cricket rules introduced into Australian schools. Former Australian cricket captain Kim Hughes and Peter Russell-Clarke participate.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 25]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is a series of scenarios based on a question which is also the title of the reel: ‘Where is it?’ and features Kenneth’s son-in-law Bob Wootton as the person looking for the answer and responding to each segment. Kenneth has Bob look in a book from a bookshelf which contains the hand written sequence titles. Kenneth also uses both black and white and colour sequences to add to the more dramatic feel of the reel. Kenneth has Bob pondering the title questions through the sequences as well as laughing at the end of some. the reel ends with Bob laughing uproariously.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:57:00 first colour scenario begins with title ‘Mr McCraw’s Orchids’ showing us Mr McCraw among his orchid plants in a hothouse as well as Kenneth’s favoured individual shots of individual blooms.

00:02:29:00 we see the next sub title, ‘Eastern Beach Geelong’ followed by colour footage of children playing in the water, foreshore recreational equipment such as diving boards and waterwheels, piers and crowds on the boardwalks and swimmers in and out of the water.

00:05:18:00 several yachts appear in the sea in what could be a race.

00:05:44:00 Bob opens the book again to the sub title ‘Skating at St Moritz’ followed by a colour sequence of a large scale ice skating show involving multiple performers and skotches at St Moritz, (presumably) in Melbourne’s St Kilda.

00:07:45:00 starts with the sub titles, ‘Hobbies - What is yours? Is it Model Boats?’ with Bob gazing toward footage of some intricate model boats and ships sailing and steaming around a shallow (and what appears to be purpose built) pool. The pool is surrounded by older children who appear to be operating the models.

00:14:52:00 Bob reveals the next question ‘or is it Model Trains?’. Here Kenneth shows us a group of men who operate model trains on a track raised high enough from the ground that they are able to ride the trains which seem to operate by steam.

00:18:21:00 ‘Or is it like mine - The Camera?’. Here we see a man in a park with what looks like a ‘box brownie’ camera taking pictures of seemingly random women (though we have seen one of them in other reels).
results.title_for_label: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 25]
results.description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is a series of scenarios based on a question which is also the title of the reel: ‘Where is it?’ and features Kenneth’s son-in-law Bob Wootton as the person looking for the answer and responding to each segment. Kenneth has Bob look in a book from a bookshelf which contains the hand written sequence titles. Kenneth also uses both black and white and colour sequences to add to the more dramatic feel of the reel. Kenneth has Bob pondering the title questions through the sequences as well as laughing at the end of some. the reel ends with Bob laughing uproariously.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:57:00 first colour scenario begins with title ‘Mr McCraw’s Orchids’ showing us Mr McCraw among his orchid plants in a hothouse as well as Kenneth’s favoured individual shots of individual blooms.

00:02:29:00 we see the next sub title, ‘Eastern Beach Geelong’ followed by colour footage of children playing in the water, foreshore recreational equipment such as diving boards and waterwheels, piers and crowds on the boardwalks and swimmers in and out of the water.

00:05:18:00 several yachts appear in the sea in what could be a race.

00:05:44:00 Bob opens the book again to the sub title ‘Skating at St Moritz’ followed by a colour sequence of a large scale ice skating show involving multiple performers and skotches at St Moritz, (presumably) in Melbourne’s St Kilda.

00:07:45:00 starts with the sub titles, ‘Hobbies - What is yours? Is it Model Boats?’ with Bob gazing toward footage of some intricate model boats and ships sailing and steaming around a shallow (and what appears to be purpose built) pool. The pool is surrounded by older children who appear to be operating the models.

00:14:52:00 Bob reveals the next question ‘or is it Model Trains?’. Here Kenneth shows us a group of men who operate model trains on a track raised high enough from the ground that they are able to ride the trains which seem to operate by steam.

00:18:21:00 ‘Or is it like mine - The Camera?’. Here we see a man in a park with what looks like a ‘box brownie’ camera taking pictures of seemingly random women (though we have seen one of them in other reels).
